sections.title: Overview
sections.content: China is the world’s most populous country, located in East Asia. It is known for its ancient civilization, rapid modernization, and global influence in politics, economics, and culture.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Beijing is the capital of China, serving as its political and cultural center. Shanghai is its largest city and a global financial hub.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Chinese yuan (CNY), also known as the renminbi (RMB).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Mandarin Chinese, though many regional languages and dialects are spoken across the country.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Chinese cuisine is diverse, with famous dishes including Peking duck, dumplings, hot pot, and dim sum.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: China has vast and varied geography, including mountains like the Himalayas, deserts such as the Gobi, fertile river valleys, and long coastlines along the Pacific Ocean.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Chinese culture is one of the world’s oldest, with traditions in Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism. Calligraphy, martial arts, festivals, and family values are central to its identity.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Great Wall of China, the Forbidden City, the Terracotta Army, the Yangtze River, and modern cities like Shanghai and Shenzhen.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: China is the birthplace of paper, gunpowder, printing, and the compass—known as the Four Great Inventions.

history.event: The Xia Dynasty is traditionally considered the first dynasty in Chinese history.
The Shang Dynasty ruled, known for bronze casting, oracle bones, and early writing.
The Zhou Dynasty introduced Confucianism and Taoism, shaping Chinese philosophy.
The Qin Dynasty unified China under Emperor Qin Shi Huang, building the first Great Wall and standardizing laws, currency, and writing.
The Han Dynasty expanded trade along the Silk Road and advanced science, technology, and culture.
The Tang Dynasty marked a golden age of art, poetry, and international trade.
The Song Dynasty saw innovations in printing, gunpowder, and navigation.
The Yuan Dynasty, founded by Kublai Khan, integrated Mongol rule into China.
The Ming Dynasty built much of the Great Wall and fostered maritime exploration under Zheng He.
The Qing Dynasty was China’s last imperial dynasty, facing internal strife and foreign pressures.
The Republic of China was established after the fall of the Qing Dynasty.
The People’s Republic of China was founded under Mao Zedong after the Chinese Civil War.
Economic reforms under Deng Xiaoping opened China to global trade and modernization.
China joined the World Trade Organization, accelerating its role in global commerce.
Beijing hosted the Summer Olympics, showcasing China’s modernization and global presence.
